div.head: English Specifications
div.docAuthor: Nancy Ide, Greg Priest-Dorman, Toma≈æ Erjavec, Tamas Varadi

div.head: MSD Index
div.p: This index gives the complete list of morphosyntactic descriptions (MSDs) and their features. In the table below, the first column gives the MSD, the second its expansion into a feature-structure, the third gives the number of entries in the lexicon (71,784 entries), and the fourth gives some examples as word-form/lemma. The list was extracted form the English MULTEXT-East lexicon.

div.head: Notes
div.p: These tags do not attempt to represent distinctions found in the various compound verb-forms. These are composed of a sequence of auxiliary and non-finite verb as follows:
So there is no "aspect" attribute or "future" value, for example.

div.head: Notes
div.p: Gender, number and case irrelevant for English.

Attributive/predicative distinction reflects positional constraints - some adjectives ('mere', 'utter', etc.) only appear in prenominal position, while others ('awake', 'devoid', etc.) only appear in predicative position. Most can appear in either.
Since many English comparatives and superlatives are formed with more/most, "positive" cannot be interpreted as "neither comparative nor superlative". See "Adverbs".

div.head: MSD Index
div.p: This index gives the complete list of morphosyntactic descriptions (MSDs) and their features. In the table below, the first column gives the MSD, the second its expansion into a feature-structure, the third gives the number of entries in the lexicon (71,784 entries), and the fourth gives some examples as word-form/lemma. The list was extracted form the English MULTEXT-East lexicon.

div.head: Notes
div.p: "General" pronouns are those which are not personal, possessive, demonstrative or reflexive. The choice of these four categories is based on distributional facts, though at a rather high level of abstraction. They enter into anaphoric dependencies which are signalled morphosyntactically and are therefore (in principle) more amenable to automatic detection. Most general pronouns do not, although they too sometimes encode number information.
"WH" attribute added to allow for combination of possessive and WH in "whose".

div.head: Notes
div.p: Definite and indefinite articles represented as values of "Type".

div.head: MSD Index
div.p: This index gives the complete list of morphosyntactic descriptions (MSDs) and their features. In the table below, the first column gives the MSD, the second its expansion into a feature-structure, the third gives the number of entries in the lexicon (71,784 entries), and the fourth gives some examples as word-form/lemma. The list was extracted form the English MULTEXT-East lexicon.

div.head: Notes
div.p: No distinction has been made between different types of "modifier" adverbs ("sentence-modifying", "VP-modifying", etc.), since their distributions overlap considerably.

div.head: MSD Index
div.p: This index gives the complete list of morphosyntactic descriptions (MSDs) and their features. In the table below, the first column gives the MSD, the second its expansion into a feature-structure, the third gives the number of entries in the lexicon (71,784 entries), and the fourth gives some examples as word-form/lemma. The list was extracted form the English MULTEXT-East lexicon.

div.head: Notes
div.p: Postpositions are rare in English.
"possessive" 's and ' might be considered postpositions, especially if the alternative is to assign them to the unique membership class (where by definition they would be unrelated).

div.head: MSD Index
div.p: This index gives the complete list of morphosyntactic descriptions (MSDs) and their features. The list was extracted form the English MULTEXT-East lexicon.

div.head: Notes
div.p: Subordinating conjunctions are often identical to prepositions (before, after, since, ...).

div.head: Notes
div.p: These have not been subsumed under adjectives, pronouns, determiners, etc. because the internal structure of complex numerals is idiosyncratic.

div.head: English Attribute Index
div.p: In this section all the attributes presented in the tables are listed in alphabetical order.

div.head: English Value Index
div.p: The values presented within the tables are, in the following, listed in alphabetical order; the first column gives the name of the value, the second column its code and the third lists attributes for which the value is appropriate.
